item.title: Data from: Density triggers maternal hormones that increase adaptive offspring growth in a wild mammal
item.description: Source Dantzer, B., Newman, A.E., Boonstra, R., Palme, R., Boutin, S., Humphries, M.M. and McAdam, A.G., 2013. Density triggers maternal hormones that increase adaptive offspring growth in a wild mammal. Science, p.1235765. Data are archived at Dryad Digital Repository Background The study showed that North American red squirrel (Tamiasciurus hudsonicus) mothers from Yukon, Alaska produce faster growing pups in years with increased squirrel density. Remarkably, the researchers even showed that perceived (but not actual) density results in faster growing pups.
